useCases.title: Habitual Actions
useCases.mainExample: I work from home every day.
moreExamples: She drinks coffee every morning.
They play tennis on Saturdays.
He watches TV in the evening.
We eat dinner at 7pm.
The shop opens at 9am.
useCases.note: Use Present Simple for routines and habits that happen regularly.

useCases.title: General Truths
moreExamples: The sun rises in the east.
Cats love milk.
London is the capital of England.
Two plus two equals four.
useCases.note: Use for facts that are always true.

useCases.title: Actions Happening Now
useCases.mainExample: She is reading a book right now.
moreExamples: They are watching TV at the moment.
I am working on a project.
He is cooking dinner.
We are studying English.
useCases.note: Use for actions in progress at the moment of speaking.

useCases.title: Life Experience
useCases.mainExample: I have visited Paris three times.
moreExamples: She has never eaten sushi.
They have been to Japan.
He has seen that film.
We have met before.
useCases.note: Use for experiences up to now (time not specified).

useCases.title: Duration Until Now
useCases.mainExample: I have been working here for five years.
moreExamples: She has been studying English since 2020.
They have been waiting for two hours.
He has been living in London for ten years.
We have been playing tennis all morning.
useCases.note: Use for actions that started in the past and continue to now.

useCases.title: Completed Actions
moreExamples: She went to Paris last year.
They bought a house in 2020.
He finished university in 2019.
We met ten years ago.
useCases.note: Use for finished actions at a specific time in the past.

useCases.title: Interrupted Actions
useCases.mainExample: I was watching TV when the phone rang.
moreExamples: She was cooking when her friends arrived.
They were playing tennis when it started raining.
He was reading when I called.
We were having dinner when the lights went out.
useCases.note: Use for background actions interrupted by another action.

useCases.title: Earlier Past Action
useCases.mainExample: When I arrived, they had already left.
moreExamples: She had finished her work before she went home.
By the time we got there, the film had started.
He had never seen snow before he moved to Canada.
They had eaten all the food before we arrived.
useCases.note: Use for actions that happened before another past action.

useCases.title: Duration Before Past Action
useCases.mainExample: I was tired because I had been working all day.
moreExamples: She was exhausted because she had been running for an hour.
The ground was wet because it had been raining.
They were hungry because they had been waiting for ages.
My eyes hurt because I had been reading for hours.
useCases.note: Use for duration leading up to a past moment.

useCases.title: Predictions
useCases.mainExample: I think it will rain tomorrow.
moreExamples: She will probably pass her exam.
The team won't win the match.
I think he will like this present.
They will be late.
useCases.note: Use for predictions based on opinion.

useCases.title: Actions in Progress at Future Time
useCases.mainExample: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to New York.
moreExamples: At 8pm tonight, we will be having dinner.
Next week, I will be working from home.
Tomorrow at this time, she will be taking her exam.
They will be watching the match at 3pm.
useCases.note: Use for actions that will be in progress at a specific future time.

useCases.title: Completed by Future Time
useCases.mainExample: By next year, we will have been married for ten years.
moreExamples: She will have finished by 5pm.
They will have left before you arrive.
I will have completed the course by June.
He will have read all the books by the end of the month.
useCases.note: Use for actions that will be completed before a future time.

useCases.title: Duration Until Future Time
useCases.mainExample: By 2025, I will have been working here for ten years.
moreExamples: Next month, she will have been studying English for five years.
In June, they will have been living in London for a decade.
By the end of the year, he will have been teaching for twenty years.
Next week, we will have been waiting for a month.
useCases.note: Use for duration leading up to a future point.
